snippet: Four candidates are thought to be in the running to succeed Hakimullah Mehsud, in an opaque process rived with tribal rivalry and personality-driven tensions.
abstract: Pakistani Taliban leaders gather to choose successor to their leader Hakimullah Mehsud, who was killed by American drone strike, as mainstream political leaders step up criticism of United States and vow to press ahead with peace talks; four candidates are thought to be in the running to succeed Mehsud, in an opaque process rived with tribal rivalry and personality-driven tensions.

byline.original: By DECLAN WALSH, ISMAIL KHAN and SALMAN MASOOD
byline.contributor: Declan Walsh reported from London; Ismail Khan from Peshawar, Pakistan; and Salman Masood from Islamabad, Pakistan. Ihsanullah Tipu Mehsud contributed reporting from Islamabad, and Zia ur-Rehman from Karachi, Pakistan.

lead_paragraph: Four candidates are thought to be in the running to succeed Hakimullah Mehsud, in an opaque process rived with tribal rivalry and personality-driven tensions.

headline.main: Pakistani Taliban Gather to Select Successor to Leader Killed in U.S. Drone Strike
headline.print_headline: Pakistani Taliban Gather to Select Successor to Leader Killed in U.S. Drone Strike
